'''Idles''' (stylised as '''IDLES''') are a British [[Rock music|rock]]<!-- Please see musical style section below and do not edit this - instead please discuss changes to the defined genre of the band in the [[Talk:Idles (band)]] page where there is a current Request for Comment --> band formed in [[Bristol]] in 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/blogs/nme-radar/idles-interview-2017-foo-fighters-2143877|title=Idles: Snarling punk that encapsulates the state of the nation|last=Smith|first=Thomas|date=29 September 2017|website=NME|language=en-US|access-date=31 August 2019}}</ref> The band consists of [[Joe Talbot (musician)|Joe Talbot]] (vocals), Mark Bowen (guitar), Lee Kiernan (guitar), Adam Devonshire (bass) and Jon Beavis (drums). Their debut album, ''[[Brutalism (album)|Brutalism]]'', was released in 2017 to critical acclaim,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/reviews/album/idles-joy-act-resistance-review|title=Idles – 'Joy As An Act Of Resistance' review|last=Bassett|first=Jordan|website=NME|language=en-US|access-date=31 August 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2018/nov/03/idles-review-academy-oxford|title=Idles review – shout their name from the rooftops|last=Empire|first=Kitty|date=3 November 2018|work=The Guardian|access-date=31 August 2019|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref> as was their second album ''[[Joy as an Act of Resistance]]'' in 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://drownedinsound.com/releases/20416/reviews/4151983|title=Album Review: Idles - Joy as an Act of Resistance|website=DrownedInSound|language=en|access-date=31 August 2019|archive-date=31 August 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190831025255/http://drownedinsound.com/releases/20416/reviews/4151983|url-status=dead}}</ref> Their third album, ''[[Ultra Mono]]'', was released on 25 September 2020. The band released their fourth album, ''[[Crawler (album)|Crawler]]'', on 12 November 2021.

==History==
===Formation, ''Welcome'' and ''Meat/Meta'' EPs (2009–2015)===
{{Main|Welcome (Idles EP)|Meat (Idles EP)}}
Welsh frontman [[Joe Talbot (musician)|Joe Talbot]] was born in [[Newport, Wales|Newport]] and spent his late teenage years in [[Devon]].<ref name="auto">{{Cite news|url=https://www.irishnews.com/arts/2019/04/19/news/idles-we-re-a-subversive-band-that-disagrees-vehemently-with-our-government-1599379/|title=Idles a subversive band that disagrees vehemently with our government|last=McSorley|first=Kevin|date=19 April 2019|work=Irish News|access-date=2 August 2019}}</ref> Talbot and bassist Adam Devonshire met in [[sixth form college]] in [[Exeter]]. Talbot and Devonshire then both moved to Bristol where they studied at the [[St Matthias, Bristol|St Matthias]] Campus of the [[University of the West of England, Bristol|University of the West of England]] and decided to start a band.<ref name="Hamilton">Hamilton, Joe (2017) "[http://www.clashmusic.com/features/brute-force-the-contrary-world-of-idles Brute Force: The Contrary World Of IDLES]", ''[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]]'', 15 March 2017. Retrieved 8 July 2017</ref> According to Talbot, "It took us a long time to get productive because we didn't know what the fuck we were doing at all, we were fucking terrible for a long time."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.clashmusic.com/features/brute-force-the-contrary-world-of-idles|title=Brute Force: The Contrary World Of IDLES|website=Clash Magazine|language=en|access-date=31 August 2019}}</ref> Talbot and Devonshire went on to open the Bat-Cave Night Club in [[Bristol]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://notanotherindiedisco.com/Not_Another_Indie_Disco_meet_Idles.html|title=Not Another Indie Disco meet Idles|website=notanotherindiedisco.com|access-date=31 August 2019|archive-date=31 August 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190831124338/http://notanotherindiedisco.com/Not_Another_Indie_Disco_meet_Idles.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> Guitarist Mark Bowen moved from Belfast to study in Bristol and met Talbot while on the DJ circuit.<ref name="auto"/>  

The band's first release was the [[Welcome (Idles EP)|''Welcome'' EP]] in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Idles-Welcome/release/3820020|title=Idles - Welcome|website=Discogs|language=en|access-date=31 August 2019}}</ref> By 2014 the band comprised Talbot, Devonshire, guitarists Mark Bowen and Lee Kiernan, and drummer Jon Beavis.<ref name="Murray">Murray, Eoin (2017) "[http://thequietus.com/articles/22722-idles-interview Stendhal Syndrome: Idles Interviewed]", [[The Quietus]], 29 June 2017. Retrieved 8 July 2017</ref> They released a second EP, ''[[Meat (Idles EP)|Meat]]'', which saw them embrace a much harder-edged direction from their early work, and ''[[Meat (Idles EP)|Meta]]'', an EP of remixes, in 2015,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Idles-Meat-EP-Meta-EP/release/13461656|title=Idles - Meat EP / Meta EP|website=Discogs|language=en|access-date=31 August 2019}}</ref> and then started writing songs for their debut album.<ref name="Hamilton" />

===''Brutalism'' (2016–2017)===
{{Main|Brutalism (Idles album)}}
After the 2016 singles, "Well Done"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/blogs/nme-radar/idles-mary-berry-well-done-listen-759161|title=IDLES Namecheck Mary Berry On Punk Anthem 'Well Done'|last=Smith|first=Thomas|date=30 September 2016|website=NME|language=en-US|access-date=31 August 2019}}</ref> and "Divide & Conquer",<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.clashmusic.com/videos/premiere-idles-divide-and-conquer|title=Premiere: IDLES - 'Divide And Conquer'|website=Clash Magazine|language=en|access-date=31 August 2019}}</ref> the band released their first album, ''Brutalism'', in March 2017 to critical acclaim.<ref name="Hamilton" /><ref>Smith, Thomas (2016) "[http://www.nme.com/blogs/nme-radar/idles-mary-berry-well-done-listen-759161 New Music Of The Day: IDLES Namecheck Mary Berry On Punk Anthem 'Well Done']", ''[[NME]]'', 30 September 2016. Retrieved 10 July 2017</ref><ref>Murray, Robin (2016) "[http://www.clashmusic.com/videos/premiere-idles-divide-and-conquer Premiere: IDLES - 'Divide And Conquer']", ''[[Clash (magazine)|Clash]]'', 31 August 2016. Retrieved 10 July 2017</ref> [[DIY (magazine)|''DIY'' magazine]], gave it 4 stars, calling it "An exhilarating escape along frenzied rhythms and powerhouse rhythms with a ferocious commentary for guidance...as vital as it is volatile."<ref>Goodman, Jessica (2017) "[http://diymag.com/2017/03/10/idles-brutalism-album-review Idles - Brutalism]", ''DIY''. Retrieved 8 July 2017</ref> ''[[The Line of Best Fit]]'' website gave it 9/10, calling Idles "one of the most exciting British bands right now".<ref>Day, Laurence (2017) "[https://www.thelineofbestfit.com/reviews/albums/idles-are-one-of-the-most-exciting-british-bands-right-now Idles are one of the most exciting British bands right now]", Line of Best Fit, 16 March 2017. Retrieved 8 July 2017</ref> It received an 8/10 from ''[[PopMatters]]'', with Ian King calling it "bracing, caustic, and relentless".<ref>King, Ian (2017) "[http://www.popmatters.com/review/idles-brutalism/ Idles Brutalism]", ''[[PopMatters]]'', 10 March 2017. Retrieved 8 July 2017</ref> ''[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]]'' gave it a similarly positive review, calling it "A rare rock record with the rage, urgency, wit and shattering of complacency usually found in grime."<ref>"Idles - Brutalism", ''[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]]'', April 2017, p. 32</ref> Talbot's mother died after a long illness while the band was working on the album, and is pictured on the cover, along with a sculpture by Talbot and his father.<ref name="Murray" /> Her death gave Talbot and the band a new focus.<ref name="Murray" /> They toured to support ''Brutalism'', and supported [[The Maccabees (band)|The Maccabees]] on the London shows of their farewell tour,<ref>Yates, Jonathan (2017) "[http://www.getsurrey.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/everything-you-need-know-maccabees-13248719 Everything you need to know about The Maccabees farewell shows at Alexandra Palace]", getSurrey.co.uk, 28 June 2017. Retrieved 8 July 2017</ref> as well as supporting the [[Foo Fighters]] for the [[O2 Arena (London)|O2 Arena's]] 10th Birthday.

===''Joy as an Act of Resistance'' (2018–2019)===
{{Main|Joy as an Act of Resistance}}
[[File:Idles Truth Stage Glastonbury 2019 010.jpg|thumb|Guitarist Mark Bowen at [[Glastonbury Festival]] 2019]]
After several festival appearances throughout Europe, they began working on their second album, ''[[Joy as an Act of Resistance]]'', which was released on 31 August 2018.<ref name="Murray" /><ref>Beauvallet, JD, (2017) "[http://www.lesinrocks.com/2017/07/08/musique/parcels-et-idles-une-deuxieme-soiree-tout-en-contrastes-aux-eurockeennes-11963784/ Des Idles aux Parcels : une deuxième soirée tout en contrastes aux Eurockéennes]", ''[[Les Inrocks]]'', 8 July 2017. Retrieved 8 July 2017</ref><ref>Jones, Craig (2017) "[http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/idles-download-festival-2017-review-13167692 Idles at Download Festival 2017: Punk band take aim at The Sun during riotous set]", ''[[Birmingham Mail]]'', 10 June 2017. Retrieved 10 July 2017</ref> Accompanying the release of ''Joy'', the group created an exhibition in collaboration with HM Electric Gallery in London, taking place 30 and 31 August 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_pfiW6I495Q|title=Joy as an Act of Resistance Exhibition|date=31 July 2018|publisher=[[YouTube]]}}</ref>

In 2019, the band was nominated for [[Brit Award for British Breakthrough Act|Best Breakthrough Act]] at the [[2019 Brit Awards]]<ref name="Brit">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/idles-1975-dua-lipa-2019-brit-awards-nominations-2430434|title=IDLES, The 1975, and Dua Lipa amongst stars nominated for 2019 BRIT Awards|last=Daly|first=Rhian|date=12 January 2019|website=NME|language=en-US|access-date=24 January 2019}}</ref> and later won the [[Kerrang! Awards 2019|2019 Kerrang! Award]] for Best British Breakthrough Act.<ref name=Kerrang!>{{cite web|title=Kerrang! Awards 2019: Here's the Full List of Winners|url=https://www.kerrang.com/the-news/kerrang-awards-2019-heres-the-full-list-of-winners/|work=Kerrang!|access-date=19 June 2019|date=19 June 2019}}</ref> That same year, [[Joy as an Act of Resistance]] was shortlisted for the 2019 Hyundai [[Mercury Prize]]. The band performed [[Never Fight A Man With A Perm]] at the ceremony on 19 September. In December, they played various shows across the UK, including a packed concert of 10,000 at London’s [[Alexandra Palace]].

===''Ultra Mono'' (2020–present)===
{{Main|Ultra Mono}}
During the latter stages of their ''Joy as an Act of Resistance'' tour in December 2019, Idles performed three new songs which were confirmed to be from their then-unannounced third album,<ref>{{cite web |last1=Reilly |first1=Nick |title=Watch Idles play defiant new track 'Grounds' at massive Ally Pally show |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/watch-idles-play-defiant-new-track-grounds-at-massive-ally-pally-show-2585354 |website=NME |access-date=21 September 2020}}</ref> which Talbot confirmed was finished and being mixed in an interview with [[Zane Lowe]] that same month. 

Following the promotional single "Mr. Motivator" in May 2020, Talbot announced their third album, ''[[Ultra Mono]]'', in June, on [[Steve Lamacq]]'s [[BBC Radio 6|Radio 6]] show.<ref name="NME Ultra">{{Cite web|last=Skinner|first=Tom|title=IDLES announce third album 'Ultra Mono' and share new track 'Grounds'|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/idles-announce-new-album-ultra-mono-and-share-first-track-grounds-2689377|work=[[NME]]|date=16 June 2020|access-date=17 June 2020}}</ref> The album was supported by a further four singles; "Grounds", "A Hymn", "Model Village" and "War" in June, July, August and September 2020, respectively. The record also features guest appearances from [[Jehnny Beth]], [[Warren Ellis (musician)|Warren Ellis]], [[David Yow]] and [[Jamie Cullum]].<ref name="NME Ultra"/> In 2020, Idles received two nominations at the Berlin Music Video Awards: the music video "Never Fight A Man With A Perm" received a nomination for Best Animation and "Mercedes Marxist" was nominated for Best Concept.<ref name="berlin">{{Cite web|last=Berlin Music Video Awards|date=7 May 2021|access-date=7 May 2021|title=Nominees 2020|url=https://www.berlinmva.com/bmva-nominees-2020/|website=Berlinmva.com}}</ref> 

''Ultra Mono'' was released on 25 September 2020 to predominantly positive reviews, with ''[[Louder Than War (website)|Louder Than War]]'' awarding it a 10 out of 10 and describing it as "the album of their career".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Robb |first1=John |title=IDLES : Ultra Mono – album review |url=https://louderthanwar.com/idles-ultra-mono-album-review/ |website=Louder than War |access-date=21 September 2020}}</ref> In 2021 the band also received the [[Libera Awards]] as Best Punk Record 2021 for their album ''Ultra Mono'' (Partisan Records) by the [[American Association of Independent Music]] (A2IM).<ref>{{Cite web |title=A2IM Libera Awards 2021 winners |url=https://liberaawards.com/2021-winners/ |access-date=2021-09-21 |website=Liberaawards.com}}</ref> Also in 2021, the band contributed a cover of the Metallica song "[[The God That Failed (song)|The God That Failed]]" to the charity tribute album ''[[The Metallica Blacklist]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|last=He|first=Richard S.|date=2021-09-10|title=Every Metallica Blacklist cover ranked from worst to best|url=https://www.loudersound.com/features/every-metallica-blacklist-cover-ranked-from-worst-to-best|access-date=2021-10-24|website=Loudersound.com|language=en}}</ref>

==Musical style==
<!-- Please see the current Request for Comment in [[Talk:Idles (band)]] where there is currently a debate about defining the genre of the band -->
[[File:Idles - Haldern Pop Festival 2017 - Alexander Kellner - 8.jpg|thumb|Idles at Haldern Pop Festival 2017]]
The band's music has been associated with [[punk rock]]<ref>{{cite web |last1=Stiernberg |first1=Bonnie |title=How IDLES Used Punk Rock To Fight Through Grief |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/idles-joy-act-resistance-interview-713263/ |website=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=17 November 2018 |date=21 August 2018}}</ref><ref name="guard">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2017/apr/06/post-brexit-punk-austerity-anthems-2017-political-rock-resurgence| title=Post-Brexit punk and austerity anthems - 2017's political rock resurgence| last=Beaumont| first=Mark| newspaper=The Guardian| date=6 April 2017| access-date=12 December 2017}}</ref> and related genres including [[post-punk]],<ref>{{cite web |last1=Beaumont |first1=Mark |title=Idles, Joy as an Act of Resistance album review: Punk rockers place vulnerability and empathy front and centre |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/reviews/idles-album-review-joy-as-an-act-of-resistance-lyrics-tracklist-release-date-a8514296.html |website=[[The Independent]] |access-date=17 November 2018 |date=30 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/music-nightlife-news/who-idles-bristol-post-punk-15860600 |title=Who are IDLES? Bristol post-punk band nominated for best breakthrough act - Manchester Evening News |first=Matthew |last=Cooper |newspaper=[[Manchester Evening News]] |date=20 February 2019 |access-date=14 April 2019}}</ref> [[hardcore punk]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a590dc78-d100-11e7-947e-f1ea5435bcc7|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times}}</ref> and [[post-hardcore]].<ref name="Vice">{{cite web |last1=Wray |first1=Daniel Dylan |title=Meet IDLES, Punk's Most Savage Good Boys |url=https://noisey.vice.com/en_uk/article/vbxmp4/idles-band-on-tour-brooklyn-feature-2018 |website=[[Noisey]] |publisher=[[Vice Media]] |access-date=17 November 2018 |date=22 March 2018}}</ref> Singer Joe Talbot, however, rejects the punk label.<ref>[https://www.msn.com/en-nz/entertainment/music/idles-joe-talbot-were-not-a-punk-band/ar-BB16L3Gg] {{dead link|date=November 2021}}</ref> In 2017, he was quoted as saying: "We're not a post punk band. I guess we have that [[motorik]], engine-like drive in the rhythm section that some post punk bands have but we have plenty of songs that aren't like that at all."<ref name="Murray" /> At a 2018 concert in [[Manchester]], he said: "for the last time, we're not a fucking punk band".<ref>McCann, Freya (2018) "[https://www.mcr.live/live-idles-o2-ritz-19-10-18/ LIVE: IDLES @ O2 RITZ | 19.10.18]", Mcr.live, 19 October 2018. Retrieved 27 October 2018</ref>

==Members==
'''Current'''
* [[Joe Talbot (musician)|Joe Talbot]] – lead vocals <small>(2009–present)</small>
* Adam Devonshire – bass, backing vocals <small>(2009–present)</small>
* Mark Bowen – lead guitar, backing vocals <small>(2009–present)</small>, keyboards <small>(2021–present)</small>
* Jon Beavis – drums, backing vocals <small>(2011–present)</small>
* Lee Kiernan – rhythm guitar, backing vocals <small>(2015–present)</small>

'''Former'''
* Andy Stewart – rhythm guitar, backing vocals <small>(2010–2015)</small>
* [[Jon Harper]] – drums <small>(2010–2011)</small>

====Live albums====
{| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;"

! scope="col" style="width:2.5em;font-size:85%;"| [[UK Albums Chart|UK]]<br /><ref name="UK-charts" />
! scope="col" style="width:2.5em;font-size:85%;"| [[Ultratop|BEL<br />(WA)]]<br /><ref name="BEL (WA)" />
! scope="col" style="width:2.5em;font-size:85%;"| [[Scottish Singles and Albums Charts|SCO]]<br /><ref name="SCO-albums" />
! scope="col" style="width:2.5em;font-size:85%;"| [[Top Heatseekers|US<br />Heat]]<br /><ref name="US-heatseekers" />
|-
! scope="row"| ''[[A Beautiful Thing: Idles Live at le Bataclan]]''
|
* Released: 6 December 2019<ref>{{cite web|url=https://music.apple.com/us/album/a-beautiful-thing-idles-live-at-le-bataclan/1482323521 |title=A Beautiful Thing: IDLES Live at Le Bataclan by IDLES on Apple Music |website=Apple Music|access-date=12 August 2020}}</ref>
* Label: [[Partisan Records|Partisan]]
| 59 || 182 || 36 || 17
|-
! scope="row"| ''Live at Ramsgate Music Hall''
|
* Released: 24 April 2020<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ramsgatemusichall.bandcamp.com/album/idles-live-at-ramsgate-music-hall |title=IDLES - Live at Ramsgate Music Hall |website=Bandcamp |access-date=12 August 2020}}</ref>
* Label: Self-released
| — || — || — || —
|}

===Physical singles and EPs===
* ''[[Idles (Idles EP)|Idles]]'' (2011), self-released
* ''[[Welcome (Idles EP)|Welcome]]'' (2012), Fear of Fiction
* ''[[Meat (Idles EP)|Meat]]'' (2015), Balley
* ''Meta'' EP (2015), Balley
* ''Meat // Anguish'' EP (2016), Harmacy
* "Well Done" (2017), Balley
* "Divide & Conquer" (2017), Balley
* "Mother" (2017), Balley
* "Danny Nedelko" (2018) – split single with [[Heavy Lungs]]
* "Mercedes Marxist" / "I Dream Guillotine" (2019), Partisan

===Download-only tracks/singles===
* "Stendhal Syndrome" (2017), Balley
* "Rachel Khoo" (2017), Balley
* "Colossus" (2018), Partisan
* "[[Danny Nedelko]]" (2018), Partisan
* "Samaritans" (2018), Partisan
* "Great" (2018), Partisan
* "[[Never Fight a Man with a Perm]]" (2019), Partisan
* "Mr. Motivator" (2020), Partisan
* "Grounds" (2020), Partisan
* "A Hymn" (2020), Partisan
* "Model Village" (2020), Partisan

===Compilations===
* ''Meat / Meta'' (2019), Balley

===Guest features===
* ''Wish '' (from the [[Anna Calvi]] album, ''Hunted'')
* ''None of Us Are Getting Out of This Alive'' (from [[The Streets]] mixtape, ''None of Us Are Getting Out of This Alive'')
